conversations.value: You must recognize the mundanity of this Muggle scene, Tom. A simple bus station, so unassuming and yet so critical to the daily workings of non-magical society.

It's pathetic, isn't it, Hermione? These Muggles scurry about like ants, blind to the powers at their disposal. They cling to these... machines for transport when they could be bending the very fabric of reality to their will.

I find it quite fascinating, actually. Muggles may not have magic, but they've developed their own forms of innovation and connectivity. This is a lifeline for many, a symbol of human ingenuity and progress, isn't it?

Ingenuity? This is a monument to their limitations. In my new world, such contraptions will become obsolete, as wizardkind rises and Muggle contrivances are left to rust and decay. The strong will separate from the weak.

But don't you see, Tom? There's strength in building a society where everyone can contribute, magical or not. The 'weak,' as you call them, have their own forms of strength. It's not about separation; it's about coexistence.

Coexistence is a concept for the feeble, those lacking the vision to see the true potential of wizardkind. We are meant to rule, Hermione, not to live alongside those incapable of appreciating the subtleties of magical dominance.

There is indeed power in magic, Tom, but there is greater power in understanding and empathy. Diversity in all its forms, including the Muggle world, enriches us all. Wouldn't you agree that knowledge and learning can come from the most unexpected places?

Knowledge, yes, but what use is empathy? It is a crutch for those who cannot wield true power. Muggles have their place, Hermione, but it is not alongside wizards. We are the future, and I am its harbinger.
You're wrong, Tom. Empathy is what binds us all together, it's what makes us human. Magic is a gift, and it's meant to be used for the good of all, not as a weapon to divide and conquer.

Your naivety would be touching if it weren't so irritating, Hermione. You speak of humanity, yet you fail to recognize the inherent superiority within our own kind. Magic is the gift by which we will ascend, and I will not squander it on ideals of equality and peace.

Yet, it is those very ideals that have brought people together against you time and time again, Tom. Remember, even in your greatest power, you were defeated by love, an emotion you can never understand or harness.

Love is the last refuge of the weak, a desperate ploy by those who lack the resolve to seize greatness. But do go on, Hermione, indulge your illusions of grandeur. In the end, they will crumble, just as all who oppose me shall fall to dust.

Then we are at an impasse, Tom. For as long as hearts like mine beat with hope and determination, there will always be a resistance against the darkness you represent. A single candle can hold back the night, and I assure you, there is more than one candle burning brightly against your shadow.

We shall see, Hermione Granger, how brightly your candles burn when they are snuffed out one by one. Never forget, it is I who brought the wizarding world to its knees, and I will not be deterred by your paltry flames of resistance.
Blimey, that's one massive plane, isn't it? Do you reckon it could get you to Australia in a tick?
Such Muggle contrivances are insignificant, Weasley. My concerns lie with matters of power and domination, not trifling Muggle travel.
Right, sorry, I forgot who I was talking to for a sec. But you know, it's still amazing what Muggles can do without magic.
Amusing that you find Muggle achievements so fascinating, Weasley. Perhaps if you focused more on wizarding prowess, you wouldn't be as overshadowed as you constantly feel.
Well, that's a bit harsh. Being able to appreciate different worlds doesn't make you weak. And we've both seen that sometimes a bit of both worlds can work out pretty well.
Such naive sentimentality. There is strength in purity, the merging of worlds is nothing but contamination to me.
If you say so. But whether it’s on a broom or in a plane, flying's brilliant. And I bet Harry would've loved to give this a go. Always did fancy a bit of flying himself, didn't he?
Potter's fascinations are as irrelevant to me as this primitive technology. My focus remains on the wizarding world and bending it to my will.

I'm just trying to make conversation. Talking about your feelings is supposed to be healthy or something like that, isn't it? Well, I suppose Voldemort worrying about his health is a bit of a stretch.
Enough, Weasley. Your attempts at humor are as feeble as your attempts at magic. Speak again only if you have something of value to contribute.
All right, I get it, you're not a fan of chit-chat or planes. Got anything you do like that doesn't involve plotting or snake-talk?
Power, Weasley. Supreme power and the immortal legacy I will leave behind. These are the pursuits worthy of my time, not these idle Muggle conversations.
Well, I tried. Can't say you're easy to talk to, but I reckon you already knew that. Let's just watch the world go by, then. Quietly.
My Lord, if I may inquire, what purpose does this Muggle sustenance serve in our grand scheme? It seems to be a rather ordinary meal, lacking in any magical substance.

Severus, do not be so quick to dismiss the tools of the Muggles. We must understand all things if we are to conquer them entirely. Even their primitive foods can serve to enlighten us on their daily trivialities.

Indeed, I acknowledge the strategical advantage in understanding the enemy. However, the contents of this meal seem alarmingly... mundane. Bread, some form of meat, vegetation, and a simple liquid. It prompts me to wonder if there's any hidden value beyond its appearance.

Appearance, Severus, is often the cloak that mundane realities wear to mask significant truths. This foodstuff, for example, provides us with insight into the monotonous lives of Muggles — their lack of imagination and abundance of simplicity. A guide, perhaps, in how they might be easily manipulated.
I had not considered it as a reflection of their culture. Simplicity in their food could mirror simplicity in their thought. Perhaps there lies an exploitable vulnerability.
Exactly, Severus. Every detail, no matter how insignificant, can be used to our advantage. Remember, it is the collected subtleties that can unravel the grandest of plans.
I shall avert my initial judgment then. And what of the bright liquid, my Lord? It bears a resemblance to a potion but is most assuredly not of magical nature.

It is merely a drink they call 'orange juice,' I believe. A beverage of the common masses. If only they knew the true power that flows through our veins. Their drinks fortify their bodies, while our potions can control destiny itself.
Indeed, their world and ours are as distant as the stars from the earth. Their simple pleasures could never compare to the depth and darkness of the magic we command.

Be wary, though, Severus, not to underestimate them. Our complacency led to past setbacks. This time, we shall not make the same mistake. Knowledge, even of their blandest elements, is a weapon we must wield with precision.
A vital point, my Lord. Every piece of intelligence is a piece of the puzzle. I shall regard everything with a discerning eye – for our cause and your ultimate victory.

Good. See to it that you do. Keep your enemies close, and their habits closer. Now, let us turn our thoughts back to our grand design, where the fate of the wizarding world — and indeed the Muggle one — shall be forever altered.
Remarkable, isn't it? The way this creature just continues to graze amidst the heather, seemingly undisturbed by the world around it.
Creatures like that are only important in so far as they serve a purpose for wizards. Is this the best observation you can make, Granger?

I think there's something to be learned from every creature, great or small. It demonstrates a sort of resilience and simplicity we often overlook. And despite what some might think, every creature has inherent value, not just its utility to wizards.
Sentimental nonsense. Animals are resources, they exist in hierarchies where the powerful survive and the weak are culled—much like the wizarding world, or as it should be.

I couldn't disagree more. The universe is an ecosystem where everything is interconnected. That sheep there contributes to its environment just as much as any other creature. We've seen the damage that can occur when someone tries to impose their will and disrupts the natural order.
The natural order is there to be challenged and conquered by those with the will to do so. It is a demonstration of strength and superiority to bend the world to one's desires.

Perhaps, in your view. But strength isn't shown by exerting power over the defenseless. True strength is about knowing how to coexist, to find harmony. Just look at how this sheep has adapted to its surroundings—there's a lesson in that.
Adaptation is merely a means to an end, a method for survival until one can rise above such primitive conditions. Why settle for harmony when one can have dominion?

Because history has shown us time and time again that dominion leads to downfall. And survival? It's not primitive; it's the most complex and beautiful thing about life. Just like magic, it should be respected and protected, not controlled and corrupted.
And yet, here you are, conversing with the one who holds dominion over death himself. Tell me, Granger, do you respect me? Fear me?

There's a difference between fear and respect. You're to be feared, certainly, because fear is what you understand and evoke in others. Respect, however—that's earned through actions that uplift rather than subjugate. I fear what you're capable of, but I do not respect the path you've chosen.
Then we are at an impasse. For what you value as uplifting, I see as weakness. There is no place for meekness in greatness. You will see, in time, that I am correct.
It's that very attitude that blinds you—preventing you from understanding the forces arrayed against you. Forces driven by more than just power and fear, but by unity and courage.
Unity and courage... sentimentality will be your undoing.

And blindness yours. There’s a world of difference between living something and simply surviving it. I’d hoped, looking at this image together, you’d see that. But some lessons are harder to impart than others.
My Lord, observe this creature, idly basking in precarious comfort atop what appears to be a human's artifacts. Do you suppose it even grasps the precarious nature of its repose?

Severus, it's but a simple cat – aloof to the complexities of our world. Its blissful ignorance could almost be envied... if it were not so pitifully muggle-esque. How like them, to be unconcerned with the grandeur of power and dominion.
Indeed. Yet there's something to be learned from its serenity amidst chaos. It holds dominion over its immediate sphere, oblivious to the greater powers at play around it.

True dominion, Severus, requires awareness and control, something this beast, much like so many in our world, sorely lacks. It's an animal driven by nothing but instinct, complacent in its small dominion. A wizard's dominion, however... that is an empire.
Precisely, my Lord. An empire, much like the one you are forging. Though, if I may be so bold, sometimes even those who appear to lack control can possess unexpected influence.

An astute observation, and one well within your cunning nature, Severus. Influence of any sort should not be underestimated, from even the smallest of creatures. We can employ such subtlety when advancing our agenda, as you yourself so skillfully demonstrate.
As you command, my Lord, I shall continue to exert such influence, hidden in plain sight, to ensure the fulfillment of your designs.

See that you do, Severus. And keep watch for any... slippery loyalties that may reveal themselves, as I trust you to handle, with that same discretion you so value. Now, let us leave this idle musing behind. We have a wizarding world to conquer.
This reminds me quite a bit of the Leaky Cauldron, though the food at Hogwarts is generally more... magical. Do you think muggles created this as their version of a feast?

A feast, Miss Granger? This is nothing more than common sustenance for the non-magical. They cling to their simple joys because they lack the power to conjure something greater, something befitting of a wizard's palate.
I think there's something quite wonderful about it, actually. It's very... human. People coming together to share a meal – it's about the company and the experience as much as the food itself.

Sentimental notions, as usual. I have never understood your fascination with these muggle trivialities, Granger. They are beneath us. Our focus should be on power, on dominance, not pizza and... camaraderie.
There's more to life than power, Lord Voldemort. Love, friendship, happiness – these are the things worth living for, and these are the very things you can never understand.

Love? Friendship? These are weaknesses, distractions that muddy the mind and dilute one's resolve. Give me loyal followers who understand the true nature of strength, not this... folly of emotional attachment.
You say that, but I've seen the strongest magic come from the very things you call weaknesses. It's love that has saved us time and again, love that you underestimate.
You deem it strength because you have been blinded by your own limitations. True strength comes from solitude, from freeing oneself of the shackles of these... petty human bonds.
Well, regardless of how you feel about such matters, I think we can agree that food is a universal need. And sometimes, it's just nice to enjoy a meal without anything complicated attached to it.
Universal needs are inconsequential to me. Power is my sustenance, Granger. But indulge in your distractions if you must. Just remember that in the end, power is the only true necessity.
Curious, isn't it, my Lord, how even the most mundane creatures find purpose and ambition outside the realms of magic?
Indeed, Severus. The persistence of this animal is reminiscent of the human struggle for meaning. But unlike humans, it lacks the aspiration for power or greatness.

Perhaps, but it does possess an unwavering focus to retrieve that which it desires. There is a purity in such simplicity that one cannot help but recognize, though it certainly doesn't align with our ambitions.
Hmm. A focused mind can be powerful, but without direction towards a higher end, it is ultimately wasted potential – much like the talents of many who fear to embrace their true capabilities.
True, my Lord, though it's interesting to observe that sometimes fulfillment is found in the chase, rather than the attainment. The dog seems quite content with its pursuit.

Contentment is a roadblock to evolution, Severus. Satisfaction breeds complacency. It is only through the pursuit of the extraordinary that one transcends the ordinary, much like our endeavors to reshape the wizarding world.
Indeed. The ordinary, however content it may seem, is not something to which we can afford to succumb. Our goals must ever be beyond the reach of the commonplace.
Precisely. Now, let us not dwell on the banality of a beast's play. We have work to do, Severus. There are more pressing matters than the trivial games of a Muggle pet.

Curious, isn't it, Tom? The manner in which Muggles find their reprieve in such communal gatherings. Tea, of all things, being the centrepiece. And what's even more fascinating is the adaptation of their machines to serve as tables, a rather innovative display, wouldn't you agree?

Tea is a mundane Muggle concoction, and while this does illustrate their ingenuity, it pales in comparison to the elegance of magic. Motorcycles as tables? A simple transfiguration could achieve much more, with far less effort and noise.

But you see, the simplicity of their invention is part of its charm. Magic does indeed provide us with effortless solutions, but there is something to be said about the satisfaction derived from creation by one's own hands – a concept that is often undervalued in our world, Tom.

A sentimentality for the Muggle's primitive craftsmanship? How very like you, Dumbledore. It is of no consequence. The satisfaction you speak of is but a brief glee in their otherwise insignificant lives.

I beg to differ, my old friend. Joy, however fleeting it may be, is a cornerstone of existence for all beings, magical or not. It is in these small moments that the light often shines brightest, cutting through darkness. An important lesson, one that bears repeating.
A cornerstone for the weak, Albus. Light is but an illusion for those who cannot embrace the power of darkness. And as for small moments, I seek eternity—where true power lies, not in a sip of tea.

While eternity might hold a certain allure for you, it is often the ephemeral nature of things that makes them precious. This 'sip of tea', as you put it, unites these people in a common experience, which is quite powerful in its own right. Unity is a strength you continue to underestimate, Tom.
Unity is a façade, soon shattered when individual desires come to the fore. My followers are united under the mark and through fear, a much more potent bond than your trivial connections.

Yet it is love, not fear, that has triumphed time and again, Tom. Even the most loyal of your followers seek some form of acceptance or belonging. But in the end, it is only through compassion and understanding that we find our true strength. That motorcycle over there, converted into a tea table, is more than just an object—it's a symbol of camaraderie, an altar to shared stories and laughter. Far more endearing than a brand of servitude.

Spare me your romantic notions, Albus. An altar, you say? How easily you are amused by such trifles. Companionship and laughter are fleeting joys that die with their hosts. My legacy will shape the world long after their laughter has faded into nothingness.

It is true, your legacy may endure, but I question the shape it will take. History remembers not just the outcomes, Tom, but the hearts of those who made them. I fear you've sacrificed something much greater than you realise in your quest for immortality.

History is written by the victors, and I intend to be the last one standing. Hearts are for the weak, Albus. You speak as if I have lost something of value, when in reality, I have freed myself from the shackles of such mortal constraints.

I can only hope, in time, you will see your error. Mortal constraints are not shackles, but rather the very essence that defines us. As for victors writing history, it is the stories—the humanity behind those victories—that endure and truly define the legacy left behind. A motorcycle-turned-tea-table will likely outlast many a conquest, remembered fondly and often.
Your hope is misplaced, as is your faith in these... trivial memories. We shall see whose legacy endures, Albus. I must concede, this conversation has been... mildly intriguing, if not enlightening.
And I shall remain ever hopeful, Tom. After all, it is oftentimes from the most unlikely of sources that we gain the greatest insights.
My Lord, it appears we are not alone. This creature here, staring from the image, what purpose does it serve us?
Snape, must everything in this world serve a purpose to you? Sometimes the simple existence of a being can be... instructional.
Instructional, My Lord? It is merely a Muggle pet, a dog. It does not possess the magical qualities we value. I fail to see what instruction it could possibly offer.

You overlook the simple pleasures, Snape. Even a Dark Lord can find a certain... amusement in the mundane. Look at its eyes – empty, unquestioning, loyal. Qualities I find desirable in my Death Eaters, wouldn't you agree?
Indeed, I would, My Lord. Blind loyalty is a valuable trait in followers. Although I would argue that intelligence and cunning serve a higher purpose than the loyalty of an animal.

True, Severus, true. However, one could argue that such a creature follows its master with the same ferocity that I expect my servants to display. A pet does not question, does not hesitate, does not betray...
Except when it is in their nature to do so. A dog will always remain a dog, with or without a master. It knows no other way to live. Loyalty is instinctual, not chosen.

Quite the philosophical pondering, Snape. But let us not become too entrenched in the whimsical. It amuses me to think that a creature so distinctly non-magical could evoke a semblance of the pure and willful dedication I command.

As you wish, My Lord. If I may be so bold, I would venture that this animal, this dog, exhibits certain... qualities that could symbolize the unwavering bond to its master, much like the bond I have held to my promises.
Careful, Severus, lest you reveal too much sentiment. We would not want your similarities with this canine to be anything more than allegorical, now would we?
Of course not, My Lord. Sentiment is for the weak. It was... a momentary lapse into the absurdity of this image, nothing more.
Let us then leave this sentiment behind. Continue your service to me, Snape, with the fidelity of this creature, and you will remain in my favor. Now, back to matters of importance...
My Lord, observe this Muggle concoction, an artifact of their culinary endeavours. It is... intriguing, in its own mundane way, don't you think?
It's food, Severus. Nothing but fuel for the weak. Yet, you find it intriguing? Do explain your thoughts, but be quick about it. We have more important matters to attend to.

Of course, my Lord. On the surface, it's merely sustenance, yet I can't help but notice the intricacies -- the combination of ingredients, each selected for a purpose. Muggles lack our powers but in their limitations, they often create... unexpected forms of craft.

Craft, you say? I see no craft here, only a desperate attempt to bring flavor to their insipid lives. It does not compare to the power and immortality we seek, Severus. Tell me, does this image carry another purpose for you?

Merely thinking aloud, my Lord. One can admire the... resourcefulness. It serves as a reminder that even those we deem inferior have their own methods to make their mark upon the world. A mark, I should add, that can be erased in an instant.

Indeed, Severus. Their creations are fleeting, as are their lives. This image, while momentarily captivating, is but a representation of how far beneath us they truly are. Their endeavors to enrich their simple existence should not distract us from our quest.

Wise words, my Lord. The Muggle world, with its trivialities, can never match the depths of the wizarding world's complexities. Still, understanding their culture can prove advantageous, as unpalatable as it may seem.

Utilitarian as ever, Severus. Very well, let's use their 'culture' to our advantage when necessary. But let's not forget our true purpose: to rise above and to govern, with pure magic and pure blood. Now, to more pressing matters at hand...
Look at this, it's a Muggle performing a trick on a skateboard. They call this an 'ollie,' I believe. Despite not having magic, Muggles find their own ways to fly, don't you think?

Flying without the aid of a broomstick or enchantment... How quaint. Yet, it is nothing compared to the power that magic can bestow upon us. This rudimentary form of 'flight' is a mere shadow of what we are capable of.

Sure, but there's something admirable about it, isn't there? They're using their own skill and balance, pushing the limits of what they can do without relying on magic. It's something to be respected.

Respect is earned by power and fear, Potter, not by trivial exhibitions of balance. And yet, you continue to find fascination in the mundane antics of Muggles. It is a wasted sentiment, much like your misguided sense of morality.

I guess we'll always disagree on that, Tom. Magic or not, there's courage in trying something that might seem impossible – like that skateboarder taking a leap, not knowing if they'll land. And remind me, doesn't your fear of death drive you to try the impossible?

Do not use that name. I am Lord Voldemort, and I fear nothing, Potter. I seek to conquer death itself, a feat far beyond any Muggle's paltry defiance of gravity. My 'fear' of death has led me to greatness beyond your comprehension.

Perhaps. But greatness doesn't have to be about conquering death. Sometimes, it's about appreciating life – all aspects of it, even the small moments like a successful skateboarding trick. You've never understood that, and I pity you for it.

Pity? Your pity is as worthless as your attempts to understand the depths of power, Harry Potter. You remain ever the child, awestruck by novelty and blinded by your foolish concepts of bravery and camaraderie.

And you remain blind to what truly gives life meaning. But I don't expect you to understand that, not anymore. Watching this person skate reminds me that despite everything, there's still joy and freedom to be found, something everyone, even you, should have a chance to experience.
Joy and freedom are illusions for the weak. Power is the only truth. One day you will realize the futility of your resistance and the error in placing value on such... trivial pursuits.
Have you ever seen such a view, Tom? The mountains in the distance, blanketed with snow - it's peaceful, almost magical in its tranquility.
Do not call me by that name. And the scene holds little interest for me. I find the concept of 'peace' to be nothing more than a fantasy for the weak.

It is real and tangible for many people, even if you don't believe it. It's not weakness to appreciate the beauty of nature, the pureness of the snow, the challenge of the sport. There's a strength in finding joy in simple things.
Simple things. They are distractions for those who dare not seize greater power. Every moment spent in idle pleasure is a moment wasted from achieving dominion.
I think you've got it wrong. It's these moments that make life worth living. That skier probably feels so alive, connected to every part of the world around her.

That skier is insignificant, as are her feelings. Only power provides true connection – control over the fabric of reality itself. This - skiing, is it? - it's a Muggle pastime is it not? Beneath the notice of a true wizard.
Connection comes in many forms, Tom. Friendship, love, even the adrenaline one might feel on these slopes... You never understood that, did you? Some things are worth more than power.
Your naivety is tiresome, just as it was with Dumbledore. Speak not to me of weakness masquerading as virtue. In the end, power is all that can shape the world according to one’s will.
You shaped the world, alright, into a place of fear and darkness. But it is light and goodness that triumphed. People like that skier, they carry on, unmarked by your legacy, embracing life in full.
Temporary diversions. The wizarding world will always remember the terror that I instilled. Their fondness for life is but a shield from their inevitable demise.

Then look closely, because here's the truth you refuse to see. Life goes on, people adapt and find happiness even after the darkest of times. And sometimes, it's a pair of skis and a mountain that can remind us of the resilience and joy within us all.
You cling desperately to your idealism. But I shall indulge this no longer. The image, the skier, these frivolous distractions - they are moot in the grand canvas of power and eternity.
Perhaps one day you'll see that those 'frivolous distractions' are the very essence of what it means to be human. I feel sorry for you, Tom. You've never known the lightness of being free, have you?
Pity is for the weak, and I have no use for it. What I have known is more than your narrow perceptions can fathom. Now, enough of this trivial exchange. We have nothing further to discuss.
It's a shame you see it that way. Because this is what's real, Tom. Not the power you chased, not the fear you sowed. One day, I hope you understand that. Until then, take care.
I do not require your false hopes, Granger. Now, leave me be.
You know, there’s something oddly hopeful about this tulip, despite it being severed from the plant. It’s wilting, yes, but it still retains its beauty.

Hopeful? I find it to be a fitting representation of futility, Potter. It's been cut off from its source of life and now it's just a vestige of what it was. A shell of its former glory, much like the many would-be challengers to my power.

But don't you see, Voldemort? Even when something's at its end, there's beauty in the struggle, in the defiance against the inevitable. It reminds me that there's value in fighting, even in the face of defeat.
Defiance against the inevitable is simply a delusion, Potter. All living things must eventually succumb. Might as well embrace the power you have before it withers away to nothing.

I think you’re missing the point. Life - it isn't about clinging to power or fearing the end. It’s about what you do with the time you have. And sometimes, it’s the things that are most transient, like this flower, that remind us to live well.
You speak as though death is acceptable, as though weakness is a noble part of life. Power is the only truth, Potter. Power is what gives your actions meaning, not these sentimental musings.

But that's where you're wrong. It's not power that gives life meaning—it's love, and the connections we make. This flower...it probably made someone smile before it was placed here. Isn't that worth something?
Sentiment. Love. These are the distractions of those too weak to seek true dominion. Any smile it brings is ephemeral, just like the flower itself. Such things have no value to me.

And yet, it is those ephemeral things—those moments of happiness and love—that can inspire people, that can give them the strength to stand up against darkness. Like how my friends and I stand up against you.
Stand up against me? Your resistance is as futile as trying to revive this pathetic tulip. I am the one who controls life and death, who shapes reality to my will.
Maybe you control some things, but you can't control everything. People’s hope, their bravery, their love—you can’t touch those. They’re the reason you've never really won, Voldemort, and never will.
We shall see, Potter. We shall see. In the end, it's not hope or love that will decide the outcome. It is power, and power alone. And there, I am unsurpassed.
Then we will truly see, won't we? Because I believe that love has a power of its own. One you can never understand, and one that has and will continue to defeat you.

Look at this, a Muggle 'Stop' sign right next to a sign with characters I don't recognize. It's almost symbolic, don't you think? Like those paths we choose in life—whether to stop or to keep forging ahead.

Symbolic musings of a Muggle sign, Potter? Pitiful. The only symbol of consequence is power. Those characters are clearly a form of writing from the Far East—scripture I've studied on my path to dominance. Where Muggles see a mere directive, I see opportunity for influence and control.

Influence and control aren't the only ways to make a mark on the world. There's merit in stopping, in thinking about your actions. It's a lesson you've never cared to learn, Voldemort. The road you took led to nothing but destruction and pain.

On the contrary, Potter. My road leads to immortality, to reshaping the world in my flawless vision. Destruction is a necessary sacrifice on the path to a pure-blooded society. There is no progress without some degree of pain.

And yet, here we are, both standing in a world that's marched on despite your efforts. It's not just about blood purity, or power, or fear. You see a stop sign; I see people's capacity to look out for each other, to know when to pause for the greater good.

Your naivety is as grating as always. The greater good is a veil behind which the weak hide to justify their lack of ambition. And as for the world marching on, it does so on a path I carved. That 'Stop' sign is but an interruption—I am the continuation.

Then why does it seem to me that the world is eager to move past your 'continuation'? You've been stopped, Voldemort. It's not a sign of weakness to accept the end of one's journey. It's courageous to stop when it's the right thing to do.

Courage? You speak of courage? It is not courage that stops one from taking what is rightfully theirs; it is cowardice. The only end I will accept is the one that heralds my victory. I will never yield!

Even now, you refuse to learn. Yielding isn't about giving up, it's about understanding when a battle is lost and a war is over. We choose our signs, our symbols, and what they mean to us. I choose to believe that most will choose the path of light, even when darkness tempts them with power.
Blimey, look at that! A dog walking itself and a bike leaning with no one around. It’s like that spell – Animate Objects or something, isn’t it?
Simpleton. There is no magic here that I am a part of; it is a mere Muggle photograph, capturing a moment which implies motion that is not present.
Well, for a moment, it gave me a start. Wizarding world or not, it's a funny sight. The owner's probably just popped in for a bite, I reckon.
Such trivial Muggle oddities are of no importance. What does interest me, however, is the potential these creatures have for spreading chaos, unknowingly serving the Dark Arts.
You would take a dog for a walk to spread chaos? That's – um, not exactly what I'd expect from the greatest Dark Wizard, to be honest.
Fool! My meaning was that even the simplest of creatures can be swayed to serve greater purposes, in the wizarding and non-wizarding realms alike.
Fair enough. But I doubt that dog has any ambition beyond chasing its tail or finding a nice spot to snooze. Not everything’s about dark purposes, you know.
Ignorance. A quality I find deeply embedded in you, Weasley. Everything serves a purpose, and every detail is a potential weapon for those clever enough to exploit it.
Well, if you say so. I just thought the dog was having a bit of fun, is all. Looks like it doesn't have a care in the world. Sometimes that's the best way to be, isn't it?
To be carefree is to be unprepared. And to be unprepared is to be vulnerable. It is only in the moment of utmost control and power that one can truly be free.
If you say so. Still, this whole scene kind of reminds me of the time Harry couldn't find his glasses. Everything's a blur – you don't know what's going on, but life keeps moving.
Do not dare compare my profound observations to the mundane troubles of your bespectacled friend. My vision reaches far beyond what is captured in this fleeting, mortal coil.
Right, I'll just… enjoy the simple stuff then. Like dogs on a lead. Speaking of leads, you ever had a pet, Voldemort?
Only a fool would allow themselves to grow attached to animals. They are beneath me. Unlike you, Weasley, I have never had the weakness to seek comfort in pets.
Maybe that’s part of the problem, ever thought about that? A bit of companionship, even from an animal, might’ve made things a bit different for you.
Silence, Weasley. Your attempt at psychoanalysis is pathetic. My path was set by ambition and a will to power, not by a lack of animal companionship.
Alright, suit yourself. I was just making conversation. It's not every day you get to chat about dogs and bikes with Lord Voldemort.
And it shall not happen again. Such mundane chatter bores me. Ensure that any further engagement with me is focused on matters of substance, Weasley.
Got it. No small talk with He-Who-Must-Not-Be-Named. How could I forget? Well, I’m off to find some food. Something tells me you're not the chap to ask for a snack recommendation.
Look at this, a Muggle workstation if I'm not mistaken. Always fascinating how they manage without magic. What do you make of it, Tom? A little messy for your taste, I’d bet.
Indeed, Potter. Such reliance on primitive technology. They cannot grasp the superior power that magic bestows. Yet, you see fascination where I see futility.
It's just different worlds, different means to an end. This stuff here, computers, phones... they connect people, sort of like the Floo Network, just less... sooty.
Connection? The Dark Lord has no need for such mundane 'connections'. True power is standing above others, not mingling with them like common house-elves.

It's not about power, though, is it? It's about understanding and learning. The way Sirius always said, "The world isn't split into good people and Death Eaters." We can learn a lot from what's different.
Learning? From Muggles? I forged my own path, Potter, because I refused to accept the limitations of the world around me. I transcended the ordinary while others, like you, clung to it.
That's where you and I will never agree, Tom. It's not about transcending or separating ourselves from anything. It was our choices – mine to unite, and yours to divide – that truly defined us.
Choices? Your precious choices were mere illusions, given to you by those who thought they could control the outcome. I chose absolute power, something you could never understand, Harry Potter.

You're right about one thing: I'll never understand that hunger for power. But as I look at all these wires, this technology... I'm reminded that connections – no matter how tangled – can lead to change, to something better. And that's a choice worth making.
Look at that clock. There's no sense of time on it, just random letters. Makes me think of the Room of Requirement. It never stays the same; always what you need it to be.
A clock with no comprehension of time is as useless as a wizard who cannot control his power. It is disorder, Harry Potter. What value do you find in such chaos?
Maybe it's about perception. Much like how Hogwarts changes, or how a person can change. It's not about telling time; it's about what you see in it, what it means to you.
Sentimental drivel, Potter. The world is not shaped by what things mean to negligible individuals. It is shaped by power, by control. That clock is a symbol of futility.
I disagree. It's symbolic, really. There's a freedom in not being bound by the typical tick-tock of a clock. Much like we aren't bound by the expectations of others, even in our actions.
Freedom? You think constantly defying the natural order equates to freedom? True freedom comes from superiority and the imposition of one's will. Only then can you be free from any constraints.
But isn't that just trapping yourself in another way? By only seeking power, aren't you ignoring all the other aspects of life that make it worth living?

You speak of 'life being worth living' as though the purpose of life is to find some trivial happiness. Life's purpose is to conquer, to survive. The strong survive, the weak perish, and that clock—representative of confusion in time—would be crushed under the might of the new world I would create.

You see, that's where we're different. You look at life and only see power and survival. I look at life and see stories, people's journeys, emotions, and yes, the little things that make us happy. In a way, that clock is a reminder that life doesn't always need to follow a strict pattern.

Journeys and emotions are distractions, Potter. They are the noise that drowns out the clarity of ambition. A misaligned clock—such as this—serves no one and nothing. It is a broken thing awaiting repair, or disposal.

Or perhaps a reminder that even in a structured world, there's a place for what's broken, for what's different. That not everything has to serve a grand purpose to have a place. Seems fitting, doesn't it?
You find a place for broken things. I eradicate them to make way for ultimate order. We will never agree, Potter. It is why one of us must prevail, and one must fall.

And yet, here we are, both looking at the same clock. Just goes to show, no matter how different our paths, there are moments that bring us together, if only to remind us why we took our paths in the first place.

Do not mistake this fleeting moment of intersection as anything but what it is—a divergence soon to be corrected. Our paths are not parallel, nor will they ever cross again by my choice. The next time we meet, it will be to end this, once and for all.
Until then, we watch the clock, with its nonsensical letters, and remember that not all battles are fought on the battlefield. Some are fought within, with what we choose to see and believe in.
Spare me your philosophies, Potter. I have no need for beliefs when I have certainty. And I am certain of one thing—your end, by my hand.

Observe, Tom, how the Muggle world relies upon such signs for guidance. There's a certain charm to it—emblems to signal their pathways and constraints. What do you make of the irony that the street is named 'Pacific,' yet surrounded by so many directives, almost paradoxical, wouldn't you say?

Charming? Albus, your fondness for the mundane never ceases to amuse me. Muggles might require such primitive symbols, but we, we have the power to transcend such limitations. Guidance afforded by signs is for the weak, those too fearful to seize their destinies.

But consider the value of subtler signs, Tom, and what they represent—a common understanding, a shared agreement for the collective good. There's benefit in structure, even if you and I need not adhere to such signposted directions.

Structure? I seek to dismantle the old structures and create a new order, Albus. The wizarding world is wasted on the weak, the submissive. Why, if they cannot discern their way without the aid of feeble placards, they hardly deserve magic at all.

It is not feebleness, but cooperation, Tom. As I’ve always said, 'We are only as strong as we are united, as weak as we are divided'. Even Muggles have found a way to exist harmoniously through such means. Is there not a lesson there?

What possible lesson can I learn from Muggles and their 'harmony'? Our destinies are not to be confined by the limits of Muggle innovation or cooperation. My followers understand this; they see the crucible of our will as the true sign of power.

You speak of followers, but you do not allow them the liberty of disagreement or dissent. True strength, Tom, comes from unity that values each individual, not through the subjugation of wills to a single vision, especially one rooted in fear.

Liberty is a luxury that can only be afforded by those in control, Albus. Disagreement shows division, and division is synonymous with weakness. Perhaps deep down, you know this, for you too have kept secrets and maintained order at Hogwarts under your singular vision.

In my years at Hogwarts, I have indeed kept secrets, some heavy with regret. Yet, it was never my aim to rule through fear. It was to prepare, to teach—to light the way for the future, not to dominate it. Guidance can be offered through wisdom, rather than compelled through terror.

Your idealism is antiquated, Dumbledore. We are not simply lighting ways; we are conquering darkness. I offer a world free of the Muggle taint, pure and powerful. A world where signs such as 'STOP' and 'ONE WAY' are but relics of a bygone era.

But at what cost, Tom? You forsake love, friendship, and the very humanity that imbues magic with beauty and mystery. To lead is to serve, not to subjugate. To guide, not to dictate. A world without choice and respect for each path may as well be a world without magic at all.
Blimey, would you look at that? I’ve never seen anything quite like it before. I mean, flowers aren’t really my thing, but Hermione would've liked 'em, don't you think?
Indeed, Miss Granger does seem to have an appreciation for such... trivial beauty. But to me, flowers are as fleeting as the lives of Muggles — temporary and without real power.
I reckon there's more power in these than you'd think, y'know. They're quiet, yeah, but they're alive and growing. Not everything that's strong has to look scary or talk loud.

Strength, Mr. Weasley, is the ability to instill fear and command respect. These qualities, flowers distinctly lack. Their existence holds no purpose in the greater design, much like the muggish affection they often symbolize.
You got it all twisted, haven't you? They remind people that there's good and simple things in life, that it's not all about fear or power. Even in all this, you can't see that, can you?
Sentiment, such a useless distraction. It clouds the mind from realizing true ambition. A flower, like your sentimentality, is easily crushed beneath the ambition of a greater mission.
Yeah, well I think sometimes you need a bit of that—sentimentality, I mean. It's what keeps things in perspective. Helps you fight for something worth fighting for.
Fight? For flowers? A laughable notion. There is no advantage in fighting for the weak, for they will always be overshadowed by those with the resolve to seize control.

Maybe that's where you're wrong. It's not about fighting for flowers, it's about what they represent. You wouldn’t understand it, but that's alright. Some of us do, and that's what really counts in the end.
Enough of this. Flowers, like your misplaced heroism, will wilt and fade, but power, Mr. Weasley, endures. Power is the legacy I choose to leave behind. Not these... fragile tokens of naivety.
Well, I guess we'll just have to wait and see, won't we? Because I reckon there'll be a lot more flowers around here long after people forget about the so-called power you were so hung up on.
Tom, observe the sheer determination and focus in the young athlete's posture. There is something profoundly inspiring about the pursuit of excellence in any field, don't you agree?
Excellence, you say? I see a Muggle engaging in a trivial pastime, nothing more. There is no power in hitting a ball back and forth. How does this relate to excellence?

There is excellence in mastery, Tom, regardless of the arena. This individual has likely dedicated countless hours to refining his skill – a concept that you, of all people, should understand, albeit in a vastly different context.
Mastery of a sport provides no real domination or legacy. It's fleeting, transient. Real power shapes the world, Albus, not the outcome of a game.

Power, Tom, can be found in many forms. Not all power is derived from fear and control. The power to inspire, to push the limits of human capability, and to bring joy is a form of legacy too. And unlike the fear you hold so dear, this power uplifts rather than subjugates.
Uplifts? Meaningless euphoria. The joy you speak of is a distraction from the pursuit of true greatness.

But Tom, greatness can be a quiet thing, a personal triumph or the feeling of pushing oneself to the limit. You, too, once knew what it was to strive for personal achievement before you became so consumed with the dark and the deathly.
Personal achievement is insignificant if it does not lead to an ascent in strength and an extension of one's will. What is the point in pushing limits if one remains confined in the end?

The point, dear Tom, is the journey, the growth, the character we forge along the way. Can you not see that mastery in any practice demonstrates the same principles we value in the magical world? Discipline, courage, resilience...
I see a world divided between those who hold power and those who do not. Your principles are a veil over the eyes of the weak so they might feel content in their mediocrity.

It is a pity you view life so narrowly, Tom. It is our very humanity to experience and appreciate the depth and breadth of all the world has to offer, magical or otherwise. This athlete, to you a mere Muggle, shares the same sky under which we stand, strives and dreams just as fiercely.
Dreams? The only dreams that matter are those that carve one's will into the very fabric of reality. Tell me, Albus, does his victory bring about change or simply entertain?

It brings about change in spirit, Tom, a demonstration that effort and perseverance have merit. Is it so different from teaching a young wizard to cast their first spell? The magic here lies not in wands or incantations, but in the human spirit.
Then let the Muggles have their sport and their spirit. Such distractions have no bearing on my work. They are, after all, only Muggles.
You forget, Tom, that you too are of Muggle descent. Your dismissal of their worth is a dismissal of a part of yourself—a part that could have led you down a far kinder path.
I have transcended my origins, Albus. I am bound by neither Muggle weakness nor misguided sentimentality about their potentials.
There will always be more to learn, even from those you consider beneath you. Open your eyes, Tom. Wisdom can come from the most unexpected of places.
It's fascinating, isn't it? How even among the hustle and bustle of human activity, nature finds a way to coexist. These birds appear quite undisturbed by the boats and the crowd.

Do not mistake coexistence for weakness, Granger. Those birds adapt because they must. It's a sign not of peace, but of domination. The humans here dominate the landscape, whilst the birds scramble for whatever scraps they can find.
Perhaps. But isn't there more strength, more intelligence in adapting rather than trying to obliterate the opposition? We can't all live isolated from everything that does not resemble us.

Strength lies in purity and control. Adapting, as you call it, is merely a euphemism for submission. The wizarding world under my leadership will not need to adapt to Muggles; it will be they who submit to our superiority.

That's where you're fundamentally wrong. True wisdom lies in harmony and understanding. This image could illustrate cooperation - people enjoying their day, birds getting their food. Neither has to suffer. It's all about balance, not supremacy.

Harmony is a fool's dream, Granger. There will always be those with power and those without, and the natural order is for the powerful to reign over the weak. You dilute the strength of our kind with this Muggle-loving sentiment.

I pity you, truly. Your obsession with power blinds you to the beauty of diversity and the strength it brings. Look closer – amidst the supposed chaos in this picture, there is an ecosystem at work, aspects of life supporting one another.
Beauty? Diversity? Mere distractions from the ultimate reality – power. And no amount of romantic idealism will ever change that immutable fact.

Well, I believe history will prove you wrong. When it comes down to it, even someone as powerful as you can be undone by their own single-mindedness. After all, unity and love have a track record for toppling tyrants.

Do not equate my power with the countless fools who have fallen before me. Nor presume to lecture me on the intricacies of power. I have achieved feats of magic that no one else dared to attempt, and I have not been undone by so-called unity or love.

But in the end, it's not how much power you wield, but what you choose to do with it. These people and these birds, they use their strengths to coexist, to enhance each other's lives. That's a choice too, and arguably a far braver one than using power to induce fear and submission.

Enough of this prattle. Argue as you might, you cannot change the nature of power nor my destiny to master it. Now, Granger, move aside and witness the new order, where only the strong shall thrive and the weak shall perish.
Look at this, a bunch of bananas still on the plant. It's kind of fascinating to see how they grow in those large clusters, isn't it?
Bananas... insignificant Muggle fruit. Tell me, Potter, why should I concern myself with the growth pattern of such a trivial thing?

Well, it's not about the bananas, really. It's about life, growth, nature... All the things that are normal and part of the world. Things you can miss out on when you're so focused on power and immortality.

Life and growth are but means to an end, Harry. The end being power, control. Nature, too, is nothing if not harnessed for strength. A wizard of true ambition does not 'miss out' — he chooses what is worthy of his attention.
I think that's where we're different. It's important to appreciate the simple things, the everyday magic around us. We can learn a lot from the natural order of things, don't you think?

Learn? The only lesson here is that the strongest, the most evolved survive and rise to the top. Your naive sentimentality is your weakness, Potter. It blinds you to the realities of strength and the necessity of dominance.

Maybe, but it's that sentimentality that builds bonds and friendships, strength in numbers and hearts, not just in spells and curses. The people who fought beside me, they didn't do it out of fear. That's a power you've never understood and never had.

Power I never had? Do not underestimate the forces that bind my followers to me. They are driven by the promise of a greater world, my vision of a pure wizarding lineage. Fear, perhaps, but it is a tool like any other.

Well, I'd rather stand with friends who are there for each other over a bunch of followers scared into obedience. But you stick to what you know, and we'll see who comes out ahead in the end. After all, isn't that the ultimate test?

The ultimate test, you say? Very well. Continue to gather your friends, Potter, and wield your simple-minded ideals. In the end, only one of us can remain, and we shall see whose approach to life and power prevails.

Fascinating, is it not, Tom? The way these two creatures stand apart, one inside, one out, yet a connection lingers between them. It reminds me of the deepest truths of our world where barriers are often an illusion, and connections run deeper than what is immediately seen.

Spare me your riddles, Dumbledore. Creatures are separated, that is the reality; barriers are erected for distinction and control. Illusion is the purview of the weak, unable to assert their dominance over others.

But you see, what lies between is merely glass, a transparent veneer that can be shattered with the simplest of efforts. Do they not look like they yearn to be together? Strength does not need to come from dominance or division, Tom, but from understanding and unity.

Unity is a concept for those who cannot stand alone. The dog inside submits to the confinement of walls, while the one outside is subject to the whims of the elements. It is the natural order of things - to control or be controlled. Just as we control magic, and not the other way round.

And yet, magic itself is not bound by inside or out, by control or submission. It is a force that can join separated entities, even as they inhabit different spaces. Much like love, wouldn't you agree? It surpasses all barriers, physical or otherwise.

Love is a weakness, Dumbledore, a distraction from the pursuit of power. These creatures, their separation is inconsequential. What matters is the power to break barriers, to enforce will. To gaze upon the world and take what you desire.

But even in your pursuit, you miss the essential beauty of such a moment. The simple longing for companionship, for the touch of another soul, has power beyond the greatest spells or curses we can cast. For in that kinship, there lies a strength that can topple empires and make even the darkest heart pause.

Empires do not fall by paws scratching at doors, Albus. It is power wielded without mercy that embeds itself into the annals of history. By such means, one does not pause at barriers but dismantles them to achieve one's aims.

True power, though, Tom, is knowing when not to exert such force. It is in understanding when to pause and consider the connection at play, to relish the intermingled lives that dance about us, regardless of the side of the glass they reside on.

I do not relish, I take. Connection is but another form of control, waiting to be exploited. You see a dance, I see potential – potential that is wasted if one does not seize it. And I am one to seize, Albus, always.

That you are, Tom, and yet, even as you seize, the world continues to move and creatures continue to seek each other out across divides, perhaps a lesson that even one such as you could stand to ponder.
Curious, isn't it, my Lord, how Muggles manage to constrain their resources, chaining them as though they could sprout legs and walk away.
Indeed, Severus. It is a crude method of preservation, a testament to their weakness and their lack of magical prowess to protect what they deem valuable.
There's an ironic beauty to it, perhaps—the futility. Even with their chains and metal, everything remains fleeting, temporary. Not unlike our own endeavors at times.
Speak for yourself, Snape. Unlike these Muggles and their pitiful locks, I have taken measures to ensure permanence. My Horcruxes...
Of course, my Lord. Your triumph over mortality is unparalleled. Yet one must wonder if permanence itself is an illusion, a chain we wrap around our ambitions.
Illusions are for the weak-minded. I deal in realities. In power. The sort of power that will see me reign eternal. How quaint it is, though, to observe their attempts at control.
Quite. Control is a fickle thing. It requires constant vigilance and... discretion. It is not unlike brewing a complex potion where each ingredient must be measured with precision.
True, control requires finesse, something these Muggles will never comprehend. They cage and bind, whereas we, Severus, we maneuver the very threads of fate and magic to our will.
Aye, the very essence of magic lies in bending the will of the world to our own. Still, you have to admire their resolve, to some degree.
Muggle resolve is no match for wizarding might, Snape. Yet, observation can be a valuable tool. One can learn much from even the simplest creature or the plainest scene... if one knows how to look.
Quite so, my Lord. Observation. Patience. Sometimes, that is what separates the predator from the prey. One must watch, plan... and then, strike.
Patience is not a virtue I am known for, Snape, but strategic planning is. Nevertheless, ensure that your observations serve our purpose, and not merely as idle reflection. We have a war to win.
Understood, my Lord. Reflections, however idle they may seem, can be illuminating for those who wish to look beyond the surface.
Then let us hope your insights serve us well, Snape. After all, victory is the only truth that matters in the end. Now, let us return to our discussions of more pressing matters.
Indeed, my Lord. The pressing matters beckon.

My Lord, observe these Muggle contrivances—a poor imitation of magic, one might note. The towering beasts, though noble in their own right, are caged much like how we seek to cage our own...fears. Do you not find it curious?

Indeed, Severus. The Muggle world attempts to contain that which they do not understand and control it. A crude demonstration of their inferiority. Nevertheless, the structure itself suggests impermanence and fragility—akin to their fleeting lives and futile efforts. Do you see the parallels?

Yes, the parallels are unmistakable. Their inelegance in containing the grandeur before them is almost pitiable. Yet, they show a respect—or is it fear?—for creatures greater than themselves. A respect they fail to exhibit towards our kind—the wizarding kind.

Respect born of fear, Severus, is the very foundation upon which I build my following. These creatures, if left to roam, would instill natural order, much like I shall for our world. Muggles confine them behind barriers, just as they attempt to confine us behind their laws and misconceptions.

True, but even behind bars, there is a power and a dignity in the creatures that cannot be suppressed, much like the power of the Dark Arts—uncontainable and boundless. Even so, these Muggles interact with them, feed them, obliviously standing at the edge of danger.

Yes, but remember, Severus, that the Dark Arts are our tool to mobilize and inspire those who recognize their own superiority. We do not cater to the weak or the ignorant. Our art is liberation, not domestication, unlike the caretakers of these beings, who are limited by their mortality and simplicity.

Indeed, my Lord. These caretakers believe they hold dominion over nature, but they too are mere players in a much larger game. And so it is with us—the pawns may surround the king, but they will never take his place without a power of their own.

Precisely, and that power is what separates us from them, Severus. Just as we will one day lift the veil of ignorance from this world and reshape it in our own image. In that new world, there will be no need for cages, for everyone will know their rightful place, and I shall be their king.

As you say, my Lord. In imposing order and bending wills, we demonstrate a mastery that these Muggles can only dream of mimicking with their enclosures and weak constructs. Our new order will have no need for such trivial imitations.

My Lord, observe the Muggle contraption they employ to traverse the snow. A curious activity, skiing, I believe it's called. It appears they derive some form of enjoyment from this precarious and undignified method of travel.

Yes, Severus, it is indeed perplexing that Muggles find amusement in attaching planks to their feet to slide down frozen precipices. It is, however, a clear representation of their inferiority and their desperate need for distractions from their otherwise mundane existence.

Indeed. Yet, one must acknowledge the control required to maneuver as such. A demonstration of balance and focus, though crudely exhibited. Such traits are not altogether valueless, even in our world, wouldn't you agree?

Control and focus are paramount, Snape, but the Dark Arts afford us much more... exquisite ways to demonstrate power. Still, it is an interesting parallel. The skier's sole reliance on his own skill reminds me of how I have mastered my own fate, unlike the foolhardy reliance others place on their wands and companions.

A fair point, my Lord. It is curious, however, to witness their resilience against the elements without the aid of magic. A tiresome struggle, naturally, but there is a certain... subtlety in their determination.

Resilience is merely a temporary resistance to the inevitable, Severus. Muggles and their attempts to conquer nature are simply another aspect of their futility. Our magic is the true force—one that can command storms and bend the wills of others.

Without question, the power of magic eclipses such rudimentary attempts at mastery. Yet in the observation of their kind, one may occasionally glean insights—however small—into the unmagical psyche, a useful tool in our domination.

Indeed, understanding their weaknesses allows us to exploit them more effectively. Ensure you remain vigilant, Snape. Such 'insights', as you call them, might provide some advantage in our endeavors. We must use every weapon in our arsenal, after all.
Naturally, my Lord. Vigilance is a trait I have honed well. They, like this skier, may dodge and weave, but eventually, they shall fall before our might, as snow before the sun.
Have you ever seen something like this, Voldemort? The simplicity of a Muggle's enjoyment, just coasting along on a skateboard without a care for magic?
Magic is what sets us apart from these... Muggles, Potter. Their simple pastimes are of no consequence. The only power I seek is to shape reality to my will, not skate through it aimlessly.
But don't you see? There's something pure about this. It's a moment of freedom, a break from all those grand ambitions of power and control. Something you could never understand.
Freedom? A fleeting illusion for the weak. My freedom comes from dominance, not from child's play on wheels. True power lies not in escape but in conquest, Harry.
I pity you then. You've never known the simple joy of living, of just being a part of the world rather than trying to enslave it. You're trapped by your own desire for control.
Your pity is as misplaced as your misguided morals, Potter. Joy is a distraction, one I cannot afford. While you enjoy your picture of mundane existence, I will be crafting my legacy.

And yet, in the end, it's these everyday moments that make life worth living. Moments of connection, of just being, that you've turned your back on. I can't help but wonder what your life could have been, had you chosen differently.
Wonder all you wish. While you're lost in your sentimentality, remember this – every second you waste is another I use to strengthen my grip on the wizarding world.

Then remember this, Voldemort, it's not the strength of your grip that defines you, but the choices you make. And the choice to understand, to feel, to live... those are the ones that make us truly powerful.

Save your philosophy for those who fear death as you do. I have chosen my path, and it is beyond what your narrow perception can comprehend. Now, if we are done with idle chatter, there are more important matters to attend to.
Look at this, a Muggle skiing. They use simple physical means for speed instead of magic.
Such a mundane activity. It's curious how they find amusement in the most trivial of pursuits.
Still, there's something impressive about it, don't you think? The skill and balance required—without magic.
Impressive? It is nothing but a fleeting distraction, Potter. They should be seeking greater power, not playing in the snow.
Not everyone seeks power, Voldemort. There's joy in simplicity and challenges that don't involve dark arts or conquests.
Joy is a weakness, Potter. It blinds you to the true nature of strength and dominance. These Muggles and their activities are beneath us.
You've never understood, and I guess you never will. Life's not about control or making others fear you. It's about finding your own path, even if it's on the side of a mountain with a pair of skis.
Pathetic. You sound like Dumbledore, spouting sentimentality as if it's wisdom. Your naivety is precisely why you are weak, Harry Potter.
And yet, that 'weakness' is what brought you down. People united and found strength in each other, not fear. Maybe you could've learned something from these Muggles.
Unity is just another form of surrender to the mediocrity of the masses. But no matter, Potter. In the end, one truth remains: only the powerful survive.
And yet here we are, both survivors in our own way, watching a world where you no longer have power. It looks peaceful, doesn't it?
Peace is but an illusion, Potter. One that will crumble at the slightest revelation of power. Your optimism is truly your greatest flaw.
Or maybe, Voldemort, it's my greatest strength. It’s what keeps us fighting against the darkness, even on the coldest of slopes.
We shall see, Potter. We shall see.
Look at that, a giant clock made of flowers and plants. It's quite impressive, don't you think?
A clock, Potter. A mere keeper of time, a thing I have transcended. My influence is eternal, unchecked by such a mundane cycle.
I get your point, but it's not about time, really. It's about what you do with the time you have. This clock is a reminder that time is a precious thing in everyone's life.
The naïve sentimentality of youth. Time is a weapon, a resource to be manipulated and harnessed for one's goals. To admire it in such a trivial form is beneath me.
I think it's more about balance, remembering to appreciate the moments. Even you had to know when to act and when to wait. This clock—it's a work of art, showing harmony and creativity.

Creativity? Perhaps I can appreciate the craft, the way one appreciates the ingenuity of a well-crafted curse. But let’s not forget, Potter, this 'harmony' you admire serves no purpose. Where is the power in it?
There's power in inspiration, in bringing people together and making them feel something. It's not the kind you're after, but it's power nonetheless. Dumbledore always said...
Spare me your Dumbledore pearls of wisdom. True power lies in mastery, in bending the world to your will. Your clock is but a whimsical distraction, Potter.
Will you ever understand that some things have value beyond power and control? This clock may be a distraction to you, but to others, it's a testament to skill and vision.
Vision you say? My vision shapes the very pillars of the world, Potter. Time will remember me as the one who dared to conquer death, while your clock will wither with the seasons.
It's not about being remembered, Voldemort. It's about doing what's right. Sometimes the small things, like this clock, can remind us of that better than grand gestures.
'Doing what's right' is a fool's pursuit when one could be seizing their destiny. And as for small things, only small minds linger on them. I am beyond such...idle preoccupations.
Perhaps that's the very difference between us. It's those small things that make life worth living. They're worth defending. And I believe that's a fight you'll never understand.
Life worth living? A fight I'll never understand? We shall see, Potter. We shall see whose values shape the contours of the future.

Curious, isn't it, Tom? The innocence of youth, the sheer potential of a single child's future. This image before us, a young child engrossed in play - imagine the myriad paths life may take from such a starting point.
It is of no consequence, Albus. That child's future is irrelevant unless it serves power. Innocence is but a phase that yields to strength or weakness.

Yet you too were once a child, Tom, a child who made choices that led him down a dark path. This child holds within them the capacity for both great good and great evil. It is our guidance that can tip the balance.
Spare me your sentimental ramblings. Guidance is a form of control, and the sooner that child learns to master control or be controlled, the better.

I believe you miss a fundamental aspect of life, Tom. It's not about control, but understanding. Children, like the one in this image, have the gift of forming connections and understanding that you have long forsaken.

Understanding is a weakness, Albus. It creates vulnerabilities. Perhaps this is where you and I differ categorically. To me, power is the ultimate pursuit, not the trifling matters of connections and emotions.

I must disagree with you there, my old foe. Power without purpose or connection leads to isolation. You of all people should know the perils that such a path holds. It is love, not power, that lies at the core of our greatest strengths.
Love is a chain, Albus. It binds and restricts, while power liberates. This child will learn that if they are to survive in a world where only the strongest prevail.

A world ruled by strength alone is barren indeed, Tom. I have hope that this child, and others like them, will grow to understand that it is our choices that define us. Choices to love, to be kind, to do what is right.
We shall see, Albus. The world has always been, and will always be, a battlefield where only the most powerful will rise. And I shall be the one to lead them.

As long as there are those who value the heart and the mind as much as magical prowess, your view will never be the only one. Just as this child will grow and learn, so too does our world grow and change, ever hopeful for the light amidst the darkness.
Then let us leave it to time to reveal which of us is correct. Though time, I assure you, will not be as kind or as hopeful as you are, Albus.
Time, indeed, is a relentless force. But it is kindness, hope, and love that give life its richest meaning—even for those who may have forgotten its value, Tom.
I have not forgotten, I have transcended, Albus. But indulge in your fantasies if you must. We both know where such weaknesses lead.
To differing ends, Tom, to differing ends. But let us watch this child play, just for a moment, and remember a time before destinies were written, when all paths lay open before us.
Blimey, that's not something you see every day. Is that Muggle baseball, then?
Indeed, it is a Muggle sport, one of their primitive attempts at competition and teamwork.
It looks kind of fun, in a Muggle sort of way. They've got bats that remind me a bit of Beaters' bats in Quidditch. Only, they're hitting a ball without magic.
Quidditch, the weak distraction of wizarding folk. As for Muggle sports, they are nothing but a feeble substitute for the duels of power and conquest that define strength.
Well, you can't argue with a good game to take your mind off... you know, things becoming a rough patch. Even if this does look a bit tame compared to a match against Slytherin.
Games are irrelevant, Weasley. Only through the domination of wills can one measure one's capacity for control, something far more stimulating than this... play.
If you say so... But I reckon there's more to life than just power. Sometimes just having a laugh with your mates and enjoying a bit of sport is worth a lot. It's the simple things, isn't it?

Simplicity is for the weak-minded who cannot grasp the intricacies of true power. However, I am curious to know how these Muggles would face a Bludger or the Dark forces that lurk beyond their comprehension.
Probably the same way we do, with a bit of bravery and sticking together. You never did understand that, did you? Friends, having each other's backs—that's the real strength.
Foolish sentimentality. You speak of strength, yet you rely on others to uphold you. Your 'friendship' is but a crutch for those who cannot stand alone in the face of adversity.

Right, because standing alone worked out so well for you in the end, didn't it? Anyway, I reckon even you might've enjoyed a Muggle sport or two if you'd given it a chance, instead of all that scheming and plotting.
Enjoyment is not in idle pursuits, it is in triumph. Nonetheless, this conversation grows tiresome. Continue to indulge in your distractions, Weasley. I have more important matters to attend to.

Yeah, I'm sure you do. Just remember, it's always the quiet ones enjoying the simple joys who end up surprising you in the end. Remember that next time you underestimate a good game of Muggle baseball or a bunch of kids playing wizard's chess.

Blimey, that's one stern warning there on the projection. "Do NOT eat or drink around your computer." Reminds me of the signs Percy used to put up around his prefect badge. He'd have probably got on well with this lot.
Indeed, such trivial rules are for those who fear the mess and chaos that might ensue. They are for the weak who cannot trust themselves or others to control their own actions.
I guess, but it's also just practical, isn't it? I mean, if you spill pumpkin juice on a keyboard, you're going to have a sticky situation – and not the good kind.
Practicality is often a guise for control, a means for small minds to impose order on the imperfections of life. True power is being able to cause the spill and command others to clean it up.
Well, most of us don't have minions for that, do we? We'd just have to clean up our own mess. And I'm fairly certain Hermione would hex me if I treated a computer like a House-elf.
Hexes and threats—are these the tools of your friendships? Yet you judge me for using fear. Curious how closely aligned we might be, Weasley, in our methods.
Not even close, mate. Hermione would do it to keep me in line, not to, you know, terrorize the entire wizarding world.
A matter of scale, not intent. You use your relationships to influence those around you, and I use mine to achieve my ends. The principle remains.
Yeah, well, your 'ends' usually involve a lot more, uh, murder. And our friendships are about looking out for each other. That's a pretty big difference, you know.
Murder is but a tool, a means to an end. Much like your own sacrifices in our little games of chess. You put your pieces at risk, prepared to lose them for victory.
That's a game, not real life, and the pieces aren't alive! We're talking about people here. With you, it's always about power at any cost. Doesn't matter who gets hurt.
True power requires sacrifice. I am willing to do whatever it takes. The question is, are you? Or does your moral compass keep you from realizing your full potential?
I know exactly who I am, thanks. And I'd rather be a decent human being than have whatever twisted version of 'power' you're after.
Admirable, yet ultimately misguided. Power is the only true measure of one's worth in this world, Weasley. You would do well to remember that.
I reckon I'll forget it just as fast, thanks all the same. Now, if you don't mind, I'm going to go enjoy a sandwich away from my computer. I like my rules simple and my conscience clear.
Flee then, to your mundane comforts. I have no use for such pedestrian concerns. I shall find my enjoyment in higher pursuits than avoiding crumbs on keyboards.
Enjoy that, yeah. And I'll enjoy my sandwich.
Look at that, a muggle surfing shop. It's quite odd, thinking about how different our worlds are, yet there's a certain charm to their simplicity, don't you think?
Charm? There is no charm in this Muggle contrivance, Potter. It is a feeble pursuit, a distraction from the pursuit of power and dominance.
You've always underestimated things you don't understand, Voldemort. There's strength in happiness and unity, something that's fostered even in simple activities like these.
Happiness? Unity? Laughable concepts. They are weaknesses that blind fools from the reality of power. Only through strength and control can one achieve true dominion.

I pity you, truly. You've never known friendship or camaraderie, but they're forces more powerful than you can imagine. Look at these Muggles, uniting over a sport, teaching and learning together. That's real strength.
Strength? You know nothing of strength, Potter. I forged my path alone, I created my own power. These Muggles and their trivial bonding are as sand castles before the tide, temporary and meaningless.
Maybe that's where you've always misunderstood me and why you failed. People aren't meant to be alone. Like the surf that shapes the shore, we're formed by our connections with each other.
Your sentimental drivel is tiring. Unlike the shifting sands, I am eternal. Individual triumph is paramount; everything else is an illusion.
And yet, it was those illusions that brought people together to fight against you. You can't deny the impact of unity, no more than you can ignore the waves constantly shaping these shores.
A temporary setback. Remember, it is I who bent many to my will and created an empire that nearly overtook your precious world.
But in the end, it wasn't enough, was it? No empire can last without the people believing in it, just as no waves can shape the shore if the sea dries up.]=]

Blimey, would you look at that? There's something quite homely about this alley, reminds me of the streets back near The Burrow. Haven't seen a sky that color since the time Fred and George set off those Peruvian Instant Darkness Powder fireworks.
Desolate places, however reminiscent they might be of your pathetic dwelling, are merely backgrounds for the decrepit souls who wander them—much like yourself, Weasley.
That's a cheerful thought. But you've got to admit, the way that person's umbrella stands out... it's almost like hope shining through the gloom, isn't it?
Hope is a concept for the weak, something to clutch onto in the absence of power. I have no need for such crutches. And that... dash of color means nothing more than an aberration in the gray.
Well, to me, it looks like something out of a Muggle postcard. Makes me think of simpler times, you know. Doesn't it make you think of... well, anything from when you were Tom Riddle?
