My past as Riddle was merely a stepping stone to greatness, Weasley. Tom was a name shed like an old skin. And this image? It is inconsequential to me, nothing but a reminder of the mundane world I seek to transcend.
It's kind of sad, isn't it, that you can look at a picture and not feel anything? I don't know, even in the darkest times, you've got to find something worth... Well, something worth appreciating.

Emotions are chains used by the weak to bind the strong. Your naivete is no less than I'd expect from someone of your standing, Weasley. There is nothing worth appreciating in weakness, certainly not the idle whimsy of a photograph.
Well, if you say so. Everyone's entitled to their own way of seeing things, I suppose. Even if yours is a bit... skewed.
My vision is the only one that matters in the end. Keep your delusions, Weasley. In time, all will see the world as I do... as it truly is.

I reckon we'll just have to agree to disagree on that one. There'll always be a bit of good to find, just like that spot of pink in all the gray. Anyway, it's a magic all of its own, isn't it? Finding the light, no matter what.
Magic? Such a trivial use of the word. But do indulge in your fantasies, Ron Weasley. It is fleeting, as all light is. Darkness will always prevail.

Guess you've never been one for a bedtime story, have you? Well, then. I can see there's no change in your perspective. But just remember, even the darkest of your curses can't snuff out every bit of light.
We shall see, Weasley. We shall see.
Curious, isn't it? How muggle inventions have their own form of complexity. Take for instance this bathroom setup – entirely non-magical, yet remarkably functional.
Functional? Perhaps. But it lacks any sense of power or deeper significance. A mere bathroom, Granger, is trivial in the grand scheme.

It's precisely this sort of everyday magic – if you will – that speaks to the ingenuity of muggles. They create environments to care for their needs without a wand's wave. There's a certain... what's the word... nobility in that simplicity.
Nobility? You are naive as ever. Muggles stumble in the dark, grasping for what wizards have naturally. Their contraptions are but poor imitations of our world's wonders.

With all due respect, just because it is muggle doesn’t mean it isn't without its merit. There’s a brilliance to their inventiveness, a resourcefulness that you, of all people, should be able to appreciate, given your history.

Do not presume to lecture me about my past, Granger. And do not mistake my acknowledgment of muggle resourcefulness for respect. They are and always will be inferior. That they manage anything at all is no more commendable than a child's first steps.

I think there's more to it than you’re willing to admit. It matters not whether one is a muggle or a wizard, but rather what one does with the abilities they possess. This bathroom symbolizes a kind of progress, a way in which Muggles strive to improve their world.

Progress? Your sentimentality is touching but misplaced. I care not for their world or their so-called advancements. My concerns lie with distinction, with elevating the wizarding kind to their proper place, devoid of these muggle taints.
Yet, regardless of beliefs, such spaces have served a purpose, even within our world. Moaning Myrtle's existence is tied to a bathroom, as was one of your own Horcruxes.

That was mere circumstance, Granger. My Horcruxes could have been placed within anything worthy. The location was of convenience and historical significance within Hogwarts, a once pure wizarding institution.

It all comes back to choice, doesn't it? You chose those locations, just as I choose to see the value in both worlds. It's a shame really, that someone with your talents couldn't apply them towards understanding and acceptance.
Understanding? Acceptance? How quaint. Power is derived from elevating oneself above limitations, not embracing them. There will be no further discourse on this, Granger. We are done here.
Blimey, look at that! A dog riding a motorbike... You don't reckon Sirius had something to do with this, do you?

Ridiculous. Sirius Black was a mere shadow of a wizard, far from capable of teaching a Muggle pet such… frivolities. Unlike him, my pursuits are of significance and power, not training animals for mirth.

Right, well, I just thought, you know, since he turned into a dog and all... Anyway, it's a bit funny, isn't it? This little fellow could be part of Hagrid's motorbike club in no time. Maybe teach it to chase after Death Eaters, eh?
Your humor is as feeble as your bloodline, Weasley. Entertaining the thought of an animal joining the magical community is beneath me. Such a creature poses no threat nor holds any value to my cause.

I dunno, Voldy. Never underestimate a good mate, even if they’ve got four legs and a tail. That dog looks more brave than most people. Got his goggles on and everything — ready to face a bit of wind, that one.

Do not address me with such a vulgar nickname, Weasel. Your pitiful attempts at intimacy suggest a lack of understanding of whom you speak to. I am Lord Voldemort, the Dark Lord, and I will not be likened to this... spectacle.
Sorry, didn’t mean to ruffle your robes. Just making conversation, is all. Besides, it's healthy to laugh once in a while, don't you think? I mean, look at those tiny goggles!

I do not require... laughter. It is a weakness of the common folk, a distraction from their dreary, powerless lives. And Weasley, make no mistake about our situation — this is not a whimsical gathering. We are in the midst of a conversation purely by circumstance.

Circumstance or not, it's a bit of fresh air from the usual 'I'm going to kill you, Potter' business, isn't it? Give it a rest, take a gander at something like this, and have a laugh. It's what's normal people do when they're not, you know, plotting to take over the world.

Normalcy is the plague of the weak. It is a state of being that I have risen above. My vision is the future, and it does not include trivial distractions like this... comedic creature. Now, if you have nothing of intelligence to discuss, be silent.
Alright, alright. No need to get snappy. Enjoy your future talk and all. I think I'll just enjoy this picture a bit longer. Makes me miss Fang a bit, that does.
My Lord, observe this Muggle interior. It is an exemplar of neglect, decay—a fitting allegory for the non-magical world, wouldn't you agree?
Severus, the imagery is apt indeed. The squalor, the abandonment—it resonates with the contemptible weakness of the Muggle condition, which we rise above.
Yes, My Lord. One can almost sense the despair, the mundane tragedy of life without magic. Such dreariness may well cloud the mind, rendering them even more pitiable.
Pitiable, yet in their ignoble existence, they pollute the purity of our world. It is a constant reminder that our work to cleanse the magical bloodlines is righteous and imperative.

Just so, My Lord. I perceive their crude implements . . . a stark contrast to the refined subtleties of our own methods in potions and spells. Even their basest facilities lack any semblance of enchantment.

True, Snape, there is no art in their being, no power or aspiration beyond their paltry means. We must never forget how inferior their realm is to ours, nor can we suffer it to taint the wizarding bloodline.

A sentiment I hold most fiercely, My Lord. Such a sight reminds me of the necessity to preserve the sanctity of our world, hidden and inviolable, where such a scene would be an affront to the senses of any self-respecting wizard.

You speak the truth, Severus. Every day the segregation between our worlds becomes more essential, and every day I grow closer to making it a reality. This image shall serve as a reminder of the filth we seek to purge.
I exist to serve that noble end, My Lord. Shall we dispense with such drear visuals and move towards ensuring such a future comes to pass?

My Lord, if you'd indulge my curiosity, there is something peculiar about this mundane capture. See how these Muggles invest time in their trivial pursuits. Why do you suppose they engage in such... activities?
They pass their insignificant lives in games and distractions, Severus, because they are blind to the powers that lie beyond their reach. They know nothing of the true forces at work in this world.

And yet, at times I ponder if there is merit in their ignorance. They remain unaffected by the Dark Arts or the burdens that come with such knowledge. It's... momentarily freeing, to consider a life unbound by the complexities of our existence.

Such whimsical thoughts are beneath you, Snape. Do not be swayed by the trivial lives of Muggles. Their simple pleasures are not for the likes of us who are destined for greatness. Our mission transcends such mundane pastimes.
Of course, my Lord. It was merely a fleeting observation. The stark contrast between their world and ours is... jarring at times.

We must focus on our ultimate goal, the purification of our kind and the subjugation of those who stand in our way. The Muggles and their games are irrelevant in the grand scheme, only worthy of our attention when they interfere with our plans.
Indeed. Though, it does make me wonder how different our world might be, had the prophecies guided us down alternate paths.
Prophecies are tools, Snape, means to ends. Beware the danger of dwelling on what might have been. Our focus must be on what is and what will soon come to pass, with our victory at its core.
You are correct as always, my Lord. Victory for our cause is the only future I seek to realize, with all else falling away like leaves in the autumn wind, much like this very scene before us.
Good. Let the Muggles play their games. Soon enough they, and all who oppose us, will feel the full might of our power. Stay vigilant, Severus. Our time is nigh.

This image, it's of a Muggle airplane's interior, isn't it? It's fascinating how Muggles manage to travel great distances at such heights without the use of magic. Don't you think there's something to be learned from their ingenuity?

Learned? I have no use for Muggle contrivances and their simple ways. Magic is what grants true power and mastery over the natural world. An airplane, you say? A tin can hurtling through the air. Merely a trick compared to Apparition or flying on a broomstick.

But you must admit there's a certain level of resourcefulness involved. We, as wizards, can become insular in our world. There's a whole population out there innovating, creating... thriving without magic. It's both humbling and inspiring.

Resourcefulness? Perhaps. But remember, it is the magical world that is superior in every way. Why be humbled by the achievements of lesser beings? True power is not derived from muggle inventions; it is wielded by those of us who have grasped the deeper mysteries of magic.

I believe that every being, whether magical or not, has a place in this world, and we can all contribute something of value. Cooperation, not domination, is the key to a prosperous society. You once attended Hogwarts, you must understand the importance of unity across all houses, just as there should be unity among all peoples.

Unity? A mere facade for the weak to feel safe. The only 'unity' I desire is the unity under my rule, where the wizarding bloodline remains pure and powerful. Hogwarts was but a stepping stone for me, Granger. I have no delusions about the 'importance' of intermingling with inferior blood.

It's that very belief that's led to so much needless suffering. Look at this image, these Muggles, unknowing and peaceful in their travels – they too have families, dreams, and the right to live. The ability to recognize and respect that is a sign of true strength, not just power.

Respect? For these Muggles? They exist only to serve the wizarding kind, or not at all. Your empathy is misplaced, girl. It blinds you to the true nature of power. In the end, there will be no room for weakness in my new order.

You speak of weakness, yet I see fear in your words. Fear of death, fear of insignificance. Understand, Voldemort, it's our connections – to each other, to all kinds of people – that enrich our lives, that make them worth living.

You are a fool, Hermione Granger, if you believe such sentimental drivel will sway me. My legacy will be eternal, and your talk of connections and empathy will fade into oblivion. The new world will not remember this picture... or your naive ideals.
It's strangely mundane, isn't it? Just a bike on a train. After all the magic and everything we've been through, it's calming to see something so... normal.
Calming for you, perhaps. I find it irritatingly muggle and unremarkable. Such a contraption holds no power, no grandeur. It is simply a tool for the weak who lack the ability to Apparate or fly.

Not everything has to be about power, you know. Sometimes, it's the simple things that can be the most freeing. Riding a bike, feeling the wind – it's like flying but on the ground. You've flown before, haven't you felt that freedom?

Freedom? I have flown on far greater things than a mere bicycle. The freedom I seek is not bound by the physical world, but by the domination of it. To fly unaided, to command the skies – that is a freedom deserving of my attention.
I guess we'll never agree on this. Anyway, do you think we'd ever see a witch or wizard just taking the train, blending in like this?

Wizards do not need to blend in with muggles, Potter. We should stand apart, above such trivialities. A wizard who willingly lowers themselves to the means of muggle transport is no better than a Squib.
I think that's where you're wrong. It's not about being above anyone; it's about choice and experiencing life. There's magic in the Muggle world too, just not the kind you can see.

Do not lecture me on choice, boy. I have made choices that have shaped the world. And as for this "magic" you believe exists in mundanity – it is nothing but a fleeting amusement for the weak-hearted who fear taking control of their own destiny.

You know, not everything has to be about control, either. Sometimes it's okay to just let things be, live a little. Look at this photo – that person probably has no idea they're being watched, no notion of the war we've fought. Just a moment in time, preserved.

Let things be? A concept for the idle. Time is but another thing to be mastered, Potter, not idly preserved. This "moment" you speak of - it is insignificant. Yet, if it amuses you to ponder such banalities, so be it.
Sometimes, I think you miss out on a lot by only seeing strength and power. There's so much more to life, Tom.

Careful, Potter. Do not mistake my tolerating this conversation for a change in my beliefs. I am ever known as Lord Voldemort, the greatest sorcerer in the world. Your narrow understanding of life matters little. Let us end this pointless charade.

What have we here? Such a curious little device, wouldn't you agree, Tom? It seems to be a muggle creation, one they call a "mobile phone," if I'm not mistaken. Much different than an owl, but it appears to serve a similar purpose.

Spare me your fascination with Muggle trinkets, Dumbledore. They are primitive and entirely beneath me. Yet, I cannot help but acknowledge their resourcefulness, however crude their inventions may be.

Quite right in one aspect, though they are primitive by our standards, Muggle inventions have their own kind of magic, do they not? A deep commitment to ingenuity and a testament to their resilience as a species. And look—this one carries a message of freedom, a sentiment I believe holds value for all beings.

Freedom? A laughable concept. The Muggles have no idea about the true nature of power and control. To me, this is nothing more than a reminder of the chaos that reigns in their world—a chaos we have the power to 'correct'.

Yet, it is from such chaos that greatness often emerges, Tom. Like the phoenix that rises from its own ashes, hope and progress are born from turmoil. Our choices in the face of such adversity truly shape the future. Would you not agree that having the choice is what defines us?

Your sentimentality is your weakness, Dumbledore. Choices are a luxury of the weak. The strong will guide the course of the future, and the Muggles and their technology will bow to magical superiority.

It appears I must respectfully disagree, my old foe. It is love and the choices it informs that hold the deepest power, a power that continues to elude you, I fear. This small piece of technology, in turn, allows them to connect across vast distances—much like our magic can.
Do not compare the Muggles' crude work to our sublime abilities. It is beneath us, just as they are. Holding onto such thoughts will be your undoing.

Perhaps, Tom, but remember that it is not our abilities that show what we truly are, but rather our choices. The profound connection between all souls, magic or Muggle, is not something to be lightly dismissed. After all, even you were once Tom Marvolo Riddle—a boy who made a choice, however dark its path led you.
I have transcended that name and the weakness it represented. The boy who made choices is long gone. There is only Lord Voldemort, conqueror of death.

And yet even conquerors must one day face time's inevitable march—something not even the greatest of magics can fully escape. There's a certain wisdom in the transient, Tom—a beauty in the ephemeral that seems to slip through your fingers much like the lives you've taken.

Do not mistake my intentions, Dumbledore. The lives I've taken, the power I've amassed... all serve a higher purpose. The beauty you speak of is a mask for fear. Fear of death, fear of the unknown—fears I have conquered.

For someone who claims to have banished fear, you are remarkably haunted by it. This fear has shaped your path, led you to a life devoid of the light-hearted, even whimsical joys one can find in the most mundane, such as this image before us. But then, I've always found that the heart's capacity for love is an indomitable magic of its own. It is a lesson I hoped you would one day learn, Tom.
Enough of your preaching, Dumbledore! I have learned all I need to become the master of my own fate and neither love nor Muggle contrivances will dictate the terms of my destiny.

Very well, Lord Voldemort. Our time is fleeting, as is this moment of reflection. But should you ever wish to seek the light or the path back from the darkness, know that it is never too late to make a choice—one that might change everything, even for you.

It's quite fascinating, isn't it? The way Muggles find such innovative ways to entertain themselves. Paddleboarding requires balance and strength, not unlike the challenges we've faced, though decidedly less perilous.

Amusing, perhaps, but purposeless. Such trivial Muggle pastimes could never compare to the true power that magic endows. Why float on water when you could bend it to your will or travel through it with a mere flick of your wand?

Not everything has to be about power, though. You see, it's about finding joy in the simple things, something you've never understood, Voldemort. And there's a certain strength in that — the strength to find happiness outside of ambition and control.

Happiness is a temporary and meaningless distraction for the weak. It is power that endures. It is power that carves the mark of one's will upon the world. What you interpret as strength is nothing but a fleeting illusion, Granger.

But that's where you're mistaken. Power isn't just about fear and control. It's about choices. The resilience of Muggles, their ability to find contentment in a life without magic, speaks volumes of their inner strength — a concept that seems to elude you.

You speak of choices, yet you choose blindness. The Muggles scurry about their short, insignificant lives, oblivious to the world's true workings. Their so-called inner strength is ignorance. They are beneath us, beneath me.

You underestimate them, just like you underestimate the power of the human spirit. And that, I truly believe, has always been your downfall. Everyone and everything has value, and it's the diversity of life that enriches our world — wizard and Muggle alike.
Granger, your naivety remains ever irksome. Diversity, value — naive constructs of the sentimental. There can be no equality where there is superiority. Your Muggle roots have clouded your judgment.

On the contrary, Voldemort. It's given me perspective — true perspective, on what it means to be human, whether I wield a wand or not. You may see superiority where you wish, but at the end of the day, it's our actions that define us. This person on the paddleboard might know nothing of Horcruxes or the Elder Wand, but their life is no less significant than any wizard's, including yours.

You speak of actions defining us. My actions have instilled fear into the hearts of many and have shaped the future of the wizarding world. That is the legacy that will endure, not the inconsequential ripples of a Muggle standing on a board.

Yet, here we are, observing a Muggle. You, with all your power and disdain, can't escape the fact that Muggles and their world will continue to exist and evolve, with or without your approval or interference.
